vocab.def: Switching between characters in narrative space with eye gaze and body shift.
Time expressions (YESTERDAY, NEXT-WEEK) that set sequence order.
Spatial location assigned to a person or place in a story.
Series of classifier signs that describe movement, shape, or action.
Facial expression conveying mood, tone, or character emotion.
The setup, conflict, and resolution of a narrative.

sections.heading: 1. Overview: Why Storytelling Matters
sections.body: Storytelling is central to Deaf culture. It preserves history, entertains, and teaches values. In ASL, storytelling combines handshape precision, spatial mapping, facial expression, and timing.

sections.heading: 2. Model: Two-Character Dialogue
sections.body: Watch a signer tell a short story using role-shift. Notice how eye gaze and slight body turns indicate character changes.

sections.heading: 3. Step-by-Step: Building a Narrative
sections.body:
1. Set up characters with spatial anchors.  
2. Introduce time (YESTERDAY, NIGHT).  
3. Show the event using classifiers.  
4. Add affect (surprised, happy, sad).  
5. Conclude with resolution.

sections.heading: 4. Practice Drill
sections.body: Students take turns telling a 4â€“5 sentence story about a school event. They must use at least one temporal marker and one classifier.

sections.heading: 5. Reflection & Peer Feedback
sections.body: Partners give feedback on clarity of role-shifts and emotional expression. Use checklist: Did I see clear character changes? Was emotion expressed?
